questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a component of the definition of safe and wholesome water?
questions.explanation: Water intended for human consumption must be safe and wholesome. It must be colorless. Safe and wholesome water is defined as: • Free from pathogenic agents • Free from harmful chemicals • Pleasant to taste, free from colour and odour • Usable for domestic purposes Water is said to be polluted when it does not fulfill the above criteria.
questions.chapter_heading: Water - I  Sources and purification of water

questions.question:
Question 2: In an urban PHC, an increasing number of skin diseases are being reported due to inadequate 
water supply in the region. What would be the adequate supply of water for them to meet 
their needs for all domestic purposes?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of skin diseases is suggestive of water-washed diseases caused by improper 
hygiene related to an inadequate water supply. In urban areas, 150–200 litres per capita per day is 
the recommended allowance to meet the needs for all kinds of domestic purposes. In rural areas, the set target of water supply to be achieved in India is around 50-55 litres per 
capita per day.
questions.chapter_heading: Water - I  Sources and purification of water

questions.question: Question 3: What are the norms for the required litres of water per capita per day in rural areas?
questions.explanation:
According to the National Rural Drinking Water Programme, the requirement of water in rural 
areas (areas with public water posts) is 55 litres per capita per day. This is in accordance with the 
12th Five Year Plan. For reasons of comparability, the source of water provision in rural areas should be within a 
distance of 100 metres from the household or the time taken to fetch water should not be > 30 
minutes. Note: Park textbook mentions 40-50 litres per capita per day as the norm. However, in the 12th 
five year plan period, the Government of India enhanced the rural drinking water supply norms 
from 40 litres to 55 litres per capita per day.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not a source of surface water?
questions.explanation: Shallow wells are sources of ground water. Sources of water: • Rain • Surface water: • Impounding reservoirs • Rivers and streams • Tanks, ponds and lakes • Ground water: • Shallow wells • Deep wells • Springs

questions.question: Question 6: What is the area from which water drains into impounding reservoirs known as?
questions.explanation:
The area draining into the impounding reservoirs are known as catchment areas. Impounding reservoirs are also called embankment ponds. These reservoirs are artificial lake-like 
water bodies. They are made by building an embankment or earth fill in an area into which 
natural water flows and can be stored for usage. Dams are also built to create these reservoirs. Water from these reservoirs is second in purity to rainwater but is not completely free from 
impurities. Catchment areas are the main sources of impurities in the water in impounding 538

questions.question:
Question 10: An outbreak of guinea worm disease was reported among villagers who used step wells for 
drinking water. In order to arrest the spread of disease, a decision was made to replace step 
wells with sanitary and safe wells. All of the following measures would be considered during 
its construction except:

options.a: Must be located at least 15 metres away from sources of contamination
options.b: A partition space for washing clothes and vessels
options.c: Lining must be made to a depth of 6 metres or more
options.d: Hand-pump must be made to handle rough use

questions.explanation:
Washing clothes, vessels, and bathing must be prohibited around wells to avoid contamination of 
the water. Step wells are a type of pucca wells which enable people to descend into the well to fetch water. It 
is obsolete now, as there is considerable personal contact between the user and the water which 
can pose a health hazard to the community. 539 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: What is the minimum length that the platform of a well should extend around it in all 
directions?
questions.explanation: The platform of a sanitary well should stretch for at least 1 metre around the well in all directions.
questions.chapter_heading: Water - I  Sources and purification of water

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is not a water-washed disease?
questions.explanation:
Cholera is a water-borne disease and not a water-washed disease. The diseases which are transmitted by improper hygiene and are widely related to circumstances 
where there is inadequate water supply are called water-washed diseases. Some examples of water-washed diseases are: • Conjunctivitis • Trachoma • Scabies • Typhus
questions.chapter_heading: Water - I  Sources and purification of water

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following methods of purification of water cannot be used on a large scale?
questions.explanation: Berkefeld filter is used for the purification of water on a small scale (ex: in households).
questions.chapter_heading: Water - I  Sources and purification of water

questions.question:
Question 15: During your posting as a rural medical officer, you conduct an awareness drive prior to the 
monsoon season in order to highlight the necessity of water purification. Which of the 
following methods would you not recommend for a household setup?
questions.explanation: Slow sand filter is a method of filtration used for the purification of water on a large scale.
questions.chapter_heading: Water - I  Sources and purification of water

questions.question:
Question 16: 532 
Sold by @itachibot When river water is stored properly, by how much percent does the bacterial count drop in 
the first 5-7 days?
questions.explanation:
When river water is stored properly, the bacterial count drops by as much as 90% in the first 5 – 7 
days. Purification during the storage of water is a natural process that takes place by physical, chemical 
and biological phenomena. Components of water purification include storage, filtration and 
disinfection.

Question 20: 533 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following best describes Schmutzdecke?

options.a: Layer of alum flocculate on supernatant water
options.b: Layer of algae and diatoms on supernatant water
options.c: Layer of alum flocculate on surface of sand bed filter
options.d: Layer of algae and diatoms on surface of sand bed filter

questions.explanation:
Schmutzdecke refers to the vital layer which is formed by algae, plankton, diatoms and bacteria 
on the surface of the sand bed filter.

questions.explanation:
The vital layer of a slow sand filter is also called the zoogleal layer, Schmutzdecke, or the 
biological layer.

questions.question:
Question 27: Which of the following is not a ceramic filter that can be used for small scale purification of 
water?
questions.explanation:
Filtration of water on a small scale is done by ceramic filters like Pasteur Chamberland, Berkefeld, 
and Katadyn filters. Ceramic filters are not widely used in India. The most important parts of these filters are the filter 
candles. Filter candles of the fine type help in removing bacteria but not viruses. These filter 
candles need to be cleaned periodically as they get clogged with impurities and bacteria. Types of ceramic filters include: • Pasteur Chamberland filter – It has a candle made of porcelain. Image of a Pasteur Chamberland filter is shown below: 543 
Sold by @itachibot • Berkefeld filter - it has a candle made of infusorial earth or kieselguhr. Image of a Berkefeld filter is shown below: • Katadyn filter - the surface of this filter is coated with a silver catalyst. The incoming bacteria are 
killed on contact with the surface by the oligodynamic action of silver ions which are liberated into 
the water. Image of a Katadyn filter is shown below: 544 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Water - I  Sources and purification of water
